awd_titl_txt: Development of MAS NMR RF Power and Spinning Speed Controllers and 1H-X Dipolar Recoupling Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, funded by the Chemical Measurement & Imaging Program of the Chemistry Division, supports Professor Terry Gullion of West Virginia University to develop magnetic resonance methods (analogous to those used in magnetic resonance imaging) to determine the structures of proteins in the solid phase.  Proteins are key components in the control of biological processes.  Determination of their structures can lead to better understanding of their biochemical functions.  For example, interactions of proteins on metallic nanoparticles offer potential therapies for targeting cancer cells.  To help communicate this science, Dr. Gullion and his group are developing and presenting chemistry to the public, providing educational opportunities for elementary and middle school students, and developing online tutorials for undergraduate and graduate students.

This work focuses on the development of magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) hardware and techniques.  The first goal is the development of high-stability MAS NMR hardware necessary for long-term NMR experiments.  A controller is being designed to accurately control radio-frequency (rf) power levels as needed for NMR experiments designed to determine molecular structures by dipolar recoupling.  A novel method to control the sample spinning speed during MAS NMR experiments is also being developed.  This enables NMR experiments that require rf pulse trains to be applied synchronously with the sample rotation.  A second goal is to develop MAS NMR 1H-Ag, 1H-Au, 1H-2H dipolar recoupling experiments to determine the structures of peptides chemisorbed on gold and silver nanoparticles and to determine the relative orientation between the adsorbed peptide and the metal surface.  To help undergraduate and graduate students that are just beginning to work in solid-state NMR, a series of educational tutorials describing NMR hardware is being produced and posted online.

por.por_cntn:
The funding from the National Science Foundation provided research training for students, opportunities for community outreach, and the ability to pursue basic scientific discovery.  Eight undergraduate students, two high school students, and one graduate student received training through the research program supported by the grant.  Of the undergraduate students that have since graduated, two students are now pursuing Ph.D. degrees in chemistry, two students have taken positions in industry (one with a pharmaceutical company and the other as a software engineer), and one student is in medical school.  The two high school students have since graduated from high school and both are physics majors at major universities.  The graduate student is close to finishing the requirements for his Ph.D. degree.  Over the course of the grant period, some of the undergraduate students and the graduate student have helped with my outreach program.  Each December we have provided a free, open to the public chemistry show to the community, and in May we have provided a chemistry show to a local elementary school (kindergarten and first grade).  These shows take place in the chemistry department and consist of demonstrations of chemical processes and hands-on activities.  During this grant period, an estimated 1200 children and adults have participated in this public outreach effort.  One research project pursued by our group is the study of the chemical composition of insect wings.  The physical properties of insect wings are of practical interest because of their strength and durability.  Insect wings used for flight are made of veins surrounding thin membranes.  Textbook models picture the insect wing membrane as consisting of dorsal (upper) and ventral (lower) layers of epicutical, with epicutical consisting of lipids and proteins and lacking chitin.  Chitin is the strong material associated with the exoskeleton of insects (and the hard shells of lobsters and crabs for example).  However, our work on the wing membranes of cicadas showed the presence of chitin in addition to the expected contributions from lipids and proteins.  This unexpected finding led us to also explore the wing membranes of other insects, and for all insects we have found significant levels of chitin.  These results suggest that the macroscopic structure of the insect wing membrane is not as simple as often assumed and the models of the insect wing need to be explored in greater detail.  Another major project that has been completed is the design and development of power controllers and spinning speed controllers for high-resolution solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR).  High-resolution solid-state NMR requires physically spinning the samples very rapidly and the application of high-power energy in the radiofrequency band in order to obtain spectra that allows for the determination of chemical composition and structure.  The sample spinning speed and the radio-frequency power need to be precisely controlled in order to obtain the best quality NMR spectra.  We developed microcontroller-based hardware that allow for the precise control of radio-frequency power to the NMR probe and the precise control of the sample spinning speed.  Both controllers are stand-alone units and can be easily incorporated into any existing NMR spectrometer.  These controllers are now part of our working spectrometers, and the respective designs have been published for public use.  Lastly, three of the undergraduate students and one of the high school students have designed laboratory experiments for chemical education.  One experiment is a desktop magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) experiment that has already been incorporated in our upper level undergraduate physical chemistry laboratory sequence.  The other is a hands-on, highly visual mechanical analog of a chemical reaction that uses steel balls and permanent magnets to illustrate the principles of an exothermic chemical reaction, and this experiment has been used as a demonstration in the classroom setting.
